articles.headline: Living in a Van Plastered With Hate, Bombing Suspect Was Filled With Right-Wing Rage
articles.snippet: Cesar Sayoc Jr., 56, accused of mailing 13 improvised explosive devices, had a lengthy criminal history in Florida that included felony theft, drug and fraud charges.
articles.abstract: Cesar Sayoc Jr., 56, accused of mailing 13 improvised explosive devices, had a lengthy criminal history in Florida that included felony theft, drug and fraud charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVENTURA, Fla. — On Twitter, Cesar Sayoc Jr. lashed out at immigrants, gun control advocates, and prominent Democratic politicians. On Facebook, he misspelled a racial epithet, directing it at the likes of Oprah Winfrey and former President Barack Obama.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei, Nick Madigan and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Megyn Kelly’s Crash at NBC in One Word (Hers): ‘Wow’
articles.snippet: After the host’s incendiary “blackface” remarks on her program — and middling ratings — Ms. Kelly’s lawyer is negotiating her exit with network executives.
articles.abstract: After the host’s incendiary “blackface” remarks on her program — and middling ratings — Ms. Kelly’s lawyer is negotiating her exit with network executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The four days that sank Megyn Kelly and sparked a vicious standoff inside NBC News began with a simple, cheery welcome to her “Today” show audience.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Microsoft Says It Will Sell Pentagon Artificial Intelligence and Other Advanced Technology
articles.snippet: Microsoft is talking the opposite position from Google, which said it would not provide cutting-edge artificial intelligence technology to the Defense Department.
articles.abstract: Microsoft is talking the opposite position from Google, which said it would not provide cutting-edge artificial intelligence technology to the Defense Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — Microsoft said on Friday that it would sell the military and intelligence agencies whatever advanced technologies they needed “to build a strong defense,” just months after Google told the Pentagon it would refuse to provide artificial intelligence products that could build more accurate drones or compete with China for next-generation weapons.

articles.headline: Google Workers Fume Over Executives’ Payouts After Sexual Harassment Claims
articles.snippet: Employees protested in meetings, on message boards and on Twitter about the company’s treatment of senior leaders even after finding misconduct claims against them credible.
articles.abstract: Employees protested in meetings, on message boards and on Twitter about the company’s treatment of senior leaders even after finding misconduct claims against them credible.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At Google’s weekly staff meeting on Thursday, the top question that employees voted to ask Larry Page, a co-founder, and Sundar Pichai, the chief executive, was one about sexual harassment.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Kate Conger

articles.headline: 11 Killed in Synagogue Massacre; Suspect Charged With 29 Counts
articles.snippet: The suspect in the Saturday morning attack, identified as Robert D. Bowers, 46, was in custody, law enforcement officials said. At least 11 people were reported killed.
articles.abstract: The suspect in the Saturday morning attack, identified as Robert D. Bowers, 46, was in custody, law enforcement officials said. At least 11 people were reported killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Armed with an AR-15-style assault rifle and at least three handguns, a man shouting anti-Semitic slurs opened fire inside a Pittsburgh synagogue Saturday morning, killing at least 11 congregants and wounding four police officers and two others, the authorities said.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Christopher Mele and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Cesar Sayoc, Mail Bombing Suspect, Found an Identity in Political Rage and Resentment
articles.snippet: Mr. Sayoc styled himself as a successful bodybuilder and entrepreneur in South Florida. But court records and people who knew him recalled him differently.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sayoc styled himself as a successful bodybuilder and entrepreneur in South Florida. But court records and people who knew him recalled him differently.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVENTURA, Fla. — Cesar Sayoc Jr. was a volatile nobody desperate to become a somebody.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Julie Turkewitz and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Used to Hearing ‘Shabbat Shalom,’ a Historic Jewish Enclave Rings Out With Gunshots
articles.snippet: Pittsburgh’s Squirrel Hill neighborhood is a close-knit Jewish community. Its day of worship turned into one of mourning after a gunman stormed into a synagogue.
articles.abstract: Pittsburgh’s Squirrel Hill neighborhood is a close-knit Jewish community. Its day of worship turned into one of mourning after a gunman stormed into a synagogue.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Saturday morning in Squirrel Hill has for more than 100 years meant certain familiar rituals. The handing out of prayer books as latecomers quietly arrive at temple, the genial shouts of ‘Shabbat shalom’ across neighborhood streets as friends spot old friends after services.

articles.headline: Trump’s Attacks on the News Media Are Working
articles.snippet: The journalism industry wasn’t built to withstand the torrent of unsubstantiated claims coming from @realDonaldTrump and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The journalism industry wasn’t built to withstand the torrent of unsubstantiated claims coming from @realDonaldTrump and elsewhere.

articles.headline: To Rally Voters, Democrats Focus on Health Care as Their Closing Argument
articles.snippet: Democrats in battleground Senate races, including Missouri, Arizona, Florida, West Virginia and Nevada, have embraced health care as they make their final pitches to voters.
articles.abstract: Democrats in battleground Senate races, including Missouri, Arizona, Florida, West Virginia and Nevada, have embraced health care as they make their final pitches to voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Senator Claire McCaskill isn’t subtle in reminding voters what her campaign is all about. She’s rechristened it the “Your Health Care, Your Vote” tour.

articles.headline: On Gab, an Extremist-Friendly Site, Pittsburgh Shooting Suspect Aired His Hatred in Full
articles.snippet: The social media site, a haven for neo-Nazis and other extremists, has lost support from service providers like GoDaddy and PayPal since Saturday’s massacre.
articles.abstract: The social media site, a haven for neo-Nazis and other extremists, has lost support from service providers like GoDaddy and PayPal since Saturday’s massacre.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early Saturday, moments before the police say he barged into a Pittsburgh synagogue and opened fire, Robert Bowers’s anti-Semitic rage finally boiled over as he posted one last message online.

articles.headline: Quiet Day at a Pittsburgh Synagogue Became a Battle to Survive
articles.snippet: The massacre at Tree of Life synagogue unfolded over about an hour. It ended when the gunman, Robert Bowers, surrendered to police officers.
articles.abstract: The massacre at Tree of Life synagogue unfolded over about an hour. It ended when the gunman, Robert Bowers, surrendered to police officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — As gunfire shattered the prayerful morning stillness of the Tree of Life synagogue, Barry Werber was hiding in a darkened storage room. In front of him was Melvin Wax, a longtime member of the New Light Congregation whose body now lay on the floor. Then a man stepped through a swinging door into the room.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Sabrina Tavernise and Sandra E. Garcia

articles.headline: Tree of Life Synagogue Victims Remembered as Guardians of Their Faith
articles.snippet: Many of the 11 people who died in the synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh were advanced in years. They were the steady backbone of their congregations.
articles.abstract: Many of the 11 people who died in the synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh were advanced in years. They were the steady backbone of their congregations.
articles.lead_paragraph: David and Cecil Rosenthal, brothers in their 50s, were almost always in the synagogue, greeting everyone who came with a “Good Shabbos” and a ready prayer book. Joyce Fienberg, 75, prayed there every day after her husband’s death. And Melvin Wax, 87, took on so many tasks — from leading services to changing light bulbs — that one friend described his role there as “everything but the cantor.”
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, Jennifer Medina and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: IBM to Buy Red Hat, the Top Linux Distributor, for $34 Billion
articles.snippet: The deal is a big move to bring more software developers under IBM’s wing and hints at a bigger push into cloud computing.
articles.abstract: The deal is a big move to bring more software developers under IBM’s wing and hints at a bigger push into cloud computing.
articles.lead_paragraph: IBM is making a big move to bring more software developers under its wing by acquiring Red Hat, the largest distributor of the popular open-source operating system Linux, for $34 billion.

articles.headline: Tesla Faces a Challenger in the Home Solar Business
articles.snippet: Tesla is relying on showrooms to sell electric cars, solar roofs and batteries. But a California rival has made inroads into the residential business.
articles.abstract: Tesla is relying on showrooms to sell electric cars, solar roofs and batteries. But a California rival has made inroads into the residential business.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Just four years after its founding in 2006, SolarCity had emerged as the nation’s leading rooftop solar power company. The company’s founders, with the help of their billionaire cousin, Elon Musk, set out to be the vanguard of an age in which consumers weaned themselves from dependence on utilities for their electricity.

articles.headline: Jair Bolsonaro Wins Brazil’s Presidency, in a Shift to the Far Right
articles.snippet: After choosing leftist presidents in four successive elections, Brazilians opted for a radical new course for Latin America’s largest nation.
articles.abstract: After choosing leftist presidents in four successive elections, Brazilians opted for a radical new course for Latin America’s largest nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil on Sunday became the latest country to drift toward the far right, electing a strident populist as president in the nation’s most radical political change since democracy was restored more than 30 years ago.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño and Shasta Darlington

articles.headline: For Trump, Dutiful Words of Grief, Then Off to the Next Fight
articles.snippet: President Trump’s discordant approach to national crises has thrust his leadership into the center of the national debate with about a week until the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s discordant approach to national crises has thrust his leadership into the center of the national debate with about a week until the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, Republican officials have complained privately that President Trump lacks the ability to confront moments of crisis with moral clarity, choosing to inflame the divisions that have torn the country apart rather than try to bring it together.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: ‘There Is Still So Much Evil’: Growing Anti-Semitism Stuns American Jews
articles.snippet: The attack on a synagogue in Pittsburgh is part of a wave of anti-Semitic attacks across the country and around the world.
articles.abstract: The attack on a synagogue in Pittsburgh is part of a wave of anti-Semitic attacks across the country and around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until recent years, many Jews in America believed that the worst of anti-Semitism was over there, in Europe, a vestige of the old country.

articles.headline: Brazil Election: How Jair Bolsonaro Turned Crisis Into Opportunity
articles.snippet: A troubled stint in the army and a polemic three-decade career as a lawmaker preceded Mr. Bolsonaro’s unlikely rise to the presidency.
articles.abstract: A troubled stint in the army and a polemic three-decade career as a lawmaker preceded Mr. Bolsonaro’s unlikely rise to the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Had the blade slashed a bit more of Jair Bolsonaro’s abdomen, the evangelical preacher who came to see him in the hospital might have had to prepare a eulogy about his friend’s presidential hopes being dashed by the same plague of violence that fueled his stunning rise.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño and Manuela Andreoni

articles.headline: Germany Without Angela Merkel: Unthinkable? Think Again, She Says
articles.snippet: The German chancellor is stepping down as head of the Christian Democrats, setting up a power struggle within her party.
articles.abstract: The German chancellor is stepping down as head of the Christian Democrats, setting up a power struggle within her party.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel has been a seemingly invincible figure in German politics. In office 13 years, she has been Europe’s most powerful leader, a presence so synonymous with stability Germans call her Mutti, or Mother. So it was a familiar sight on Monday to see her live on television, until she asked Germans to do something far less familiar, and “get ready for the time after me.”
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy
